title-group.article-title: Technological Catching Up, Quality of Exports, and Competitiveness: A Sectoral Perspective

abstract.p: We analyze the relationship between Central and Eastern European countries (CEEC) industry-level competitiveness and technological catching up induced by economic integration with European Union (EU) economies. A theoretical dynamic setup is developed in which high-skill firms gain market share in "quality dominated" markets, whereas low-skill firms face price competition for their exports. We run econometric estimations for bilateral trade between CEEC and EU economies over 2000–2007. We first test the assumption that the unit value ratio is a good proxy for quality in trade and then use the fitted unit value ratio to estimate the role of preference for quality in CEEC market share changes. Estimations support the results of the theoretical model.

ref.mixed-citation: Yet, economic integration per se is not sufficient for a successful catching up; the so-called advantage of relative backwardness takes place only in the presence of "absorptive capacity," that is, the availability of technological capabilities, particularly in terms of skilled workers.
To save on notation, we have omitted the time index.

Once the above two-stage static maximization problem has been solved, the optimal al- location of expenditure across time is readily obtained as the solution to a standard intertemporal maximization problem. See Cavallaro et al. (2012).
See Cavallaro and Mulino (2009b) for a similar analysis in a general equilibrium framework.

We consider international R&D spillovers, FDI, and business contacts as the means that may convey technology transfers within our theoretical framework. Keller (2004) and Lutz et al. (2008) stressed that these are among the strongest forms of knowledge diffusion. Intermediate goods, which also are emphasized in some contributions in the literature (see Maggi et al. 2009, among others), have to be excluded in our analysis, being nontraded by assumption.

For the CEEC, we consider only the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, and Slovenia be- cause data on technological variables for other countries is missing; among the EU-15 countries, we do not consider Luxembourg.

The choice of performing regressions on the overall changes instead of using panel data techniques is due to the high number of missing sectoral data, especially for domestic R&D expen- diture. Given our focus on basic long-term trends, we leave aside data referring to 2008 onward for the adverse effect of the recent global financial crisis on output growth and the volumes of trade, as well as FDI flows and R&D expenditure considered in our estimation.
We exclude Cyprus and Malta from the sample because of their small size.

We dropped observations belonging to the upper and lower 5 percent of the distribution, since large differences in unit values point to a composition effect within product categories, that is, to the presence of heterogeneous goods; in this case, it is likely that price differences are not associated with differences in the goods' quality content.

The UVR we build is analogous to the one present in Greenaway et al. (1995) and Fontagné and Freudenberg (1997), among others. Alternative measures of product quality based on export unit values have been operationalized in the literature. For instance, Hallak and Schott (2011) decomposed observed export prices into quality and pure price components, using information on consumers' evaluation of products inferred from countries' trade balances.
We replaced missing values of R&D expenditure by inputting the average value for HS and LS industries separately.
In Linder (1961) the demand for high-quality goods depends on the consumer's level of income.

Since the evolution of relative prices depends also on traditional cost determinants, we run the estimation for Equation (16) adding the growth rate of real wages and labor productivity as well. However, the results are not affected by these variables, since most of their effects are captured by the reporter- and sector-specific dummies. The results are available upon request.
In particular, partners' dummies include the effect of foreign GDP growth rate, which has to be included as a main effect, being part of the interaction term QDEM^V.
These results are available upon request.
